intro: Melampyrum pratense var. americanum, commonly known as the American touchroot, is a herbaceous plant native to North America. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, commonly referred to as the broomrape family, and is characterized by its parasitic growth habit. The plant typically grows in open woodlands and prairies, thriving in well-drained soils. It produces small, yellowish-orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and often have a reddish or purplish hue, contributing to its ornamental appeal.
